Prod cap increased in 1988; addl upgrades 1991, 1993. $11 million refit in1996. Shut-in 9/7; dock in Singapore 9/24 at Sembawang Shipyard; steel renew for 5yr life estension. Return 2/97. World's 1st disconnectable FPSO. SBM = original moor & install on fixed lumpsum contract. BHP sold FPSO 11/98 to Gulf Australia. Gulf Australia for sale by debt-laden Canadian parent. Majority/operator interest purchased by Newfield Exploration 7/99. Newfield sold its interest to Coogee Resources Pty Ltd in Sept 2003.

10/11: The conversion of Glas Dowr FPSO was done at the Sembawang Shipyard in Singapore. It has a crude oil production capacity of 50,000 barrels per day (bbl/d) and a maximum storage capacity of 647,750bbl. The FPSO is designed for extended at-sea service, with a design life of 15 years (10 years on the field without dry-docking). The hull specifications are: 242.3m length, 42m width and 21.1m depth, with a dead weight tonnage (DWT) of 105,000 tonnes.
07/11: Repairs and upgrades to extend the life of the vessel for 10 years to be done by Sembcorp. 

 

Sembcorp said work on the vessel was expected to be completed during the second quarter of 2011 for deployment in the Kitan field in the Timor Sea.

column21: The Lebanese Ministry of Energy and Water is considering proposals for a newbuild FSRU, an existing FSRU and conversions. Minimum size recommended of of 125,000 m3, with ship-based LNG vaporization at regasification capacity of up to 3.5 MMt/y of LNG equivalent.

02/08: Total has given notice to Exmar and CMB that it intends to exercise its option to purchase the FPSO Farwah.  The vessel is currently producing oil from Total's Al Jurf field, offshore Libya, where it has been operating since 2003. Total's purchase of the vessel is expected to close in May 2008, with Exmar and CMB each expected to realise a capital gain of around USD 1 million and a cash surplus of around USD 16 million from the sale. It is expected to remain on the Al Jurf field, located in a water depth of 89 msw, until 2015.
2/11: Situation unclear due to uprising in Libya.

10/12: Platform will be shipped to field in May 2016, with first gas expected in Dec 2016. Nyhamma will be expanded by around 15% to accommodate Aasta hansteen and other developments that come via the NSGI trunkline.

10/12: dimesnions 100 x 50 x 28 metres. Dimensions and cost kept down by through single train compression/decompression of produced gas. The spar has spare area and 3,500 tonnes reserved for future expansions.  The topside has 16 riser slots, of which only three will be used for the initial development. 9 trees over 2 manifolds. Aasta Hansteen developed in conjunction with NSGI which includes 500km of trunkline to shore.

03/08: FPSO now installed.

According to Lundin Petroleum the Alvheim FPSO has left Haugesund on February 15 and is now undergoing a number of tests prior to installation.  The subsea infrastructure is already in place and the five production wells are understood to be progressing for production start up at the end of March. Marathon was forced to revise its timescale for the project, which was originally due to be on stream last year, due to what it called "difficult market conditions for skilled labour".

07/14: Premier is apparently focusing on a Sevan Marine-designed cylindrical floating production unit as the base case to develop its Bream field off Norway, targeting total investments of up to Nkr10 billion ($1.6 billion). Waiting for formal award. Seven Marine Q1 results presentation (May 2014) mentioned that there are strong expectations that Seven would be directly involved in the FEED.

8/14 conversion project is expected to cost approximately $280 million, including amounts reimbursable upon delivery of the unit relating to installation and mobilization, and the cost of acquiring the remaining 33 percent ownership interest in the Randgrid shuttle tanker

04/14: PSA has advised Eni to postpone delivery of FPSO from yard as it is concerned there is still a lot of work to do, and thinks as much work should be done onshore to ensure quality of the floater. Eni has declined to say if it will take advice and still anticipates sailaway of FPSO for "summer, 2014". 
08/12: Eni has announced that Goliat has been postponed by 9 months - from the 4th quarter of 2013 to the 3rd quarter of 2014 - while the cost of development has increased 20% from its initial estimate. Entire development cost is now USD 6.2 billion (NOK 36.7 billion)- the original cost was NOK 30.5 billion.

09/08: StatoilHydro has completed the replacement of the Norne FPSO's swivel and expects the vessel to resume production within the next week.  Replacement of the swivel, which took 40 days, will see the ship's lifetime extended from 2016 to 2021. The operation was the first of its kind to be carried out at sea, with swivel replacements having previously been undertaken in dock. As well as extending the vessel's life, the swivel replacement will also enable it to receive gas and condensate from the Alve field, scheduled to come onstream by the end of 2008.

04/08: FPSO to be upgraded this year. Swivel to be replaced, increasing capacity. New swivel will contain two extra tubings. Replacement will allow FPSO to receive gas and condensate from Alve field.

Wintershall is also looking at solutions that combine a tie-back with a small floating production, storage and offloading vessel. Reserves for Skarfjell are estimated at 120 to 230 million barrels of oil equivalent.

7/12: Statoil are currently evaluating two alternative turret system designs for the selected FSU.
One alternative is a submerged turret loading (STL) system, which will consist of a STL
buoy with turret, mooring system, risers and equipment in the STL room. The Mariner
Area Development will then pre-install the buoy, complete with mooring lines and risers
before the FSU arrives. The second alternative will be to select a bottom mounted internal
turret (BMIT) system, which does not include a submerged buoy.

11/13: Work has progressed slower than expected but vessel should return to Pierce now, around 2 months behind schedule. Further installation and commissioning work needs to be completed at Pierce, including the installation of a new production riser. Work is dependent on weather conditions.

column21:
02/08: Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine has awarded a contract to KBR for provision of engineering, procurement and interface design services for topsides on Total's Pazflor FPSO.  Pazflor's design is a purpose-built FPSO with a topsides weight of 32,200 tonnes. The vessel will have a processing capacity of 200,000 b/d of oil and 150 million scf/d of gas, as well as a storage capacity of around 1.9 million barrels of crude. The FPSO will have a 20-year design life, with quarters for 220 workers. First oil from the Pazflor project, which includes the Perpetua, Acacia, Zinia and Hortensia fields, is expected in 2011. The FPSO, being built at Daewoo's fabrication yard in South Korea, will be spread-moored in 762 msw atop 25 subsea oil wells, two gas injection wells and 22 water injection wells.

10/07: Budgetry issues to be addressed before contract awards. Daewoo leading bidder for FPSO. Technip/Acergy may win subsea work.

First LPGFPSO to be installed offshore. Lease term is for 8 yrs. Maximum throughput = 37,370 bpd of lpg. Mitsui and IHI signed construction contracts with SBM to build the FPSO. Largest LPG hull ever built. First production in April 2005.

7/14: FPSO naming ceremony held on July 18 and the unit is mobilising to the project's location.
5/14: Refurbishment and conversion of the FPSO was completed at the Keppel shipyard. The unit is on its way to Angola where conversion work will be completed at the Paenal yard. First production is on-track for H2 2014.

7/12: Vaalco has agreed to a five-year extension for the lease and operation of the FPSO Petroleo Nautipa. The firm period is extended from Q3 2015 to Q3 2020, with options for a further two years. BW estimated the total revenue at USD 300 million including options - up from USD 100 million under the previous contract. The vessel will undergo a life-extension upgrade with an estimated capex of USD 30 million.

FSO will remain on field until November 2008.   Vessel previously operated on the N'Kossa field off Congo for Total. MSE in Malaysia selected by SBM for refurb and repair work in preparation for installation on Yoho. Vessel will replace SBM's FPSO Falcon 4q05.

10/11: The conversion of Glas Dowr FPSO was done at the Sembawang Shipyard in Singapore. It has a crude oil production capacity of 50,000 barrels per day (bbl/d) and a maximum storage capacity of 647,750bbl. The FPSO is designed for extended at-sea service, with a design life of 15 years (10 years on the field without dry-docking). The hull specifications are: 242.3m length, 42m width and 21.1m depth, with a dead weight tonnage (DWT) of 105,000 tonnes.
07/11: Repairs and upgrades to extend the life of the vessel for 10 years to be done by Sembcorp. 

 

Sembcorp said work on the vessel was expected to be completed during the second quarter of 2011 for deployment in the Kitan field in the Timor Sea.
